main event: On March 28, 1950, at 1340 hours, an illuminated object was reported by four people in Northern Minnesota, traveling from North to South in the vicinity of Hibbing, Minnesota.
interesting points: The object was described as having a definite greenish glow and was shaped like a plywood barrel with the size of a 55-gallon oil drum, descending at a 45-degree angle.
No visible means of support, exhaust, or propulsion were observed, and no sound was noted.
The two citizens who made the most credible reports were considered exceptionally reliable witnesses, with one of them being a foot specialist and the other a former Air Force pilot.
The object did not come near any aircraft or other objects, and it disappeared behind an obstacle.
This sighting was thoroughly investigated with no solar phenomenon or aerial testing apparatuses identified, and military, commercial, and private aircraft operations were reported as normal.
sighted object: illuminated object with a greenish glow, resembling a plywood barrel with the size of a 55-gallon oil drum
witnesses: reliable witnesses including a foot specialist and a former Air Force pilot
